ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: The course begins with a covering of tensor calculus and manifold theory (also a very silly, unrelated digression into Newton-Cartan Theory which isn't necessary or useful for anything else). Then it covers the basic Field Equations, the ADM formalism, Stellar Models, cool black holes (rotating and charged), cosmology, and gravitational waves. There are approximately weekly problem sets which were reasonable, and two take home midterms which were challenging but fun.General Relativity is a crucial tool for understanding modern Cosmology and much of theoretical physics. Whether this is a good course for covering it is questionable. People coming from an astronomy perspective would probably get a lot more out of ASTR/PHYS 600 than this course. The course as a whole is very interesting though for people who are interested in mathematical formalism and cool black hole physics.
Definitely, it is one of the most interesting things you will ever learn.
Pretty good class. Take it if you want to learn about general relativity.
Physics 538 is a great course. You will cover a lot of material, but the workload is manageable and the material is really rewarding.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: Interested in mathematical physics, so this course was pretty useful!
Did not help my dissertation (I'm an undergraduate)deepened my understanding of gravity
